values.description:
pull request #1328 modifies the `Visual::GetBoundingBox()` behavior to return bounding box dimensions without the scale applied to it. This is better and more consistent with the scene graph concept (and also consistent with how ogre manages scale and bounding box). 

This pull request fixes the test and now expects the local bounding box dimensions to remain the same
values.title: Fix visual BoundingBox test

summary.raw:
pull request #1328 modifies the `Visual::GetBoundingBox()` behavior to return bounding box dimensions without the scale applied to it. This is better and more consistent with the scene graph concept (and also consistent with how ogre manages scale and bounding box). 

This pull request fixes the test and now expects the local bounding box dimensions to remain the same
summary.html:
pull request #1328 modifies the Visual::GetBoundingBox() behavior to return bounding box dimensions without the scale applied to it. This is better and more consistent with the scene graph concept (and also consistent with how ogre manages scale and bounding box).

This pull request fixes the test and now expects the local bounding box dimensions to remain the same

values.description:
same idea as pull request #1355

Visual `GetBoundingBox()` was recently updated to return a bounding box without scale applied. This PR fixes `ModelAlign` to apply the scale manually to its calculations

Added a unit test to `ModelAlign_TEST`
values.title: Fix aligning scaled models

summary.raw:
same idea as pull request #1355

Visual `GetBoundingBox()` was recently updated to return a bounding box without scale applied. This PR fixes `ModelAlign` to apply the scale manually to its calculations

Added a unit test to `ModelAlign_TEST`

same idea as pull request #1355

Visual GetBoundingBox() was recently updated to return a bounding box without scale applied. This PR fixes ModelAlign to apply the scale manually to its calculations

Added a unit test to ModelAlign_TEST

values.description:
The build has been failing on OS X since boost 1.57 was made the default boost version in homebrew (#1399):

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/337/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/338/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/339/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/340/

This pull request fixes build with boost 1.57 due to [QT bug](https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-22829) that interacts with boost headers. This pull request requires [sdformat pull request 137](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/137/fix-gazebo-build-with-boost-157-qt-bug/diff).

I'll need to set up a gazebo-any-sdformat-any homebrew job to verify the fix. @\_jrivero_ 

UPDATE: [sdformat pull request 137](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/137/fix-gazebo-build-with-boost-157-qt-bug/diff) has been released in sdformat2 2.2.1; re-testing this pull request with a [new jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/343/)
values.title: Fix build with boost 1.57 for 2.2 branch (#1399)

values.title: Fix small bug, checking wrong message field in msgs::LinkToSDF

values.description:
As reported in [drcsim issue 455](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/455/cant-spawn-multiple-atlases):

spawning multiple Atlases using the "Insert Model" tab causes Gazebo to crash:
~~~
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::ItemIdentityException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(4:ItemIdentityException): A camera with the name default::head_hokuyo_sensor_ortho_cam already exists in OctreeSceneManager::createCamera at /build/buildd/ogre-1.8-1.8.1+dfsg/PlugIns/OctreeSceneManager/src/OgreOctreeSceneManager.cpp (line 372)
~~~

The crash is caused by a name collision in the GpuLaser class (#1403). I made a failing test, and then @iche033 fixed it.
values.title: Handle GpuLaser name collisions (#1403)

summary.raw:
As reported in [drcsim issue 455](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/455/cant-spawn-multiple-atlases):

spawning multiple Atlases using the "Insert Model" tab causes Gazebo to crash:
~~~
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::ItemIdentityException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(4:ItemIdentityException): A camera with the name default::head_hokuyo_sensor_ortho_cam already exists in OctreeSceneManager::createCamera at /build/buildd/ogre-1.8-1.8.1+dfsg/PlugIns/OctreeSceneManager/src/OgreOctreeSceneManager.cpp (line 372)
~~~

The crash is caused by a name collision in the GpuLaser class (#1403). I made a failing test, and then @iche033 fixed it.
summary.html:
As reported in drcsim issue 455:

spawning multiple Atlases using the "Insert Model" tab causes Gazebo to crash:

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::ItemIdentityException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(4:ItemIdentityException): A camera with the name default::head_hokuyo_sensor_ortho_cam already exists in OctreeSceneManager::createCamera at /build/buildd/ogre-1.8-1.8.1+dfsg/PlugIns/OctreeSceneManager/src/OgreOctreeSceneManager.cpp (line 372)

The crash is caused by a name collision in the GpuLaser class (#1403). I made a failing test, and then @iche033 fixed it.

values.description:
These issues are somehow related to each other so I solved them all on the same branch:

[#388: Building Editor: center of model not within building polygon](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/388/building-editor-center-of-model-not-within)

* Solved taking `modelOrigin`

[#1351: Building Editor: crash if Visual SceneNode is NULL](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1351/building-editor-crash-if-visual-scenenode)

[#1353: Building Editor: Individual walls manipulable, bounding box select buggy for building with default name](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1353/building-editor-individual-walls)

* Both solved by making a clear distinction between the `previewVisual` and the saved visual.

[#1373: Model name/location maintained between Building Editor sessions](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1373/model-name-location-maintained-between)

* Solved calling `gui::editor::Events::newBuildingModel();` on exit
values.title: Building Editor: Fix some issues when exiting editor

summary.raw:
These issues are somehow related to each other so I solved them all on the same branch:

[#388: Building Editor: center of model not within building polygon](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/388/building-editor-center-of-model-not-within)

* Solved taking `modelOrigin`

[#1351: Building Editor: crash if Visual SceneNode is NULL](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1351/building-editor-crash-if-visual-scenenode)

[#1353: Building Editor: Individual walls manipulable, bounding box select buggy for building with default name](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1353/building-editor-individual-walls)

* Both solved by making a clear distinction between the `previewVisual` and the saved visual.

[#1373: Model name/location maintained between Building Editor sessions](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1373/model-name-location-maintained-between)

* Solved calling `gui::editor::Events::newBuildingModel();` on exit
summary.html:
These issues are somehow related to each other so I solved them all on the same branch:

#388: Building Editor: center of model not within building polygon

  • Solved taking modelOrigin

#1351: Building Editor: crash if Visual SceneNode is NULL

#1353: Building Editor: Individual walls manipulable, bounding box select buggy for building with default name

  • Both solved by making a clear distinction between the previewVisual and the saved visual.

#1373: Model name/location maintained between Building Editor sessions

  • Solved calling gui::editor::Events::newBuildingModel(); on exit

values.description:
The gazebo build is broken with boost 1.57 (now default boost version on OS X with homebrew). The 2.2 branch was fixed by pull request #1358, but the 3.1 branch requires an additional fix for boost 1.57 and some fixes for linking to an external libccd.

Here's a [homebrew build of gazebo_3.1](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/351/) to confirm the build failure. I'll post the build results of this branch when available to confirm the fix.
values.title: Fix build with boost 1.57 for 3.1 branch (#1399)

Here's a [homebrew build of gazebo_3.1](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/351/) to confirm the build failure. I'll post the build results of this branch when available to confirm the fix.

The gazebo build is broken with boost 1.57 (now default boost version on OS X with homebrew). The 2.2 branch was fixed by pull request #1358, the 3.1 branch was fixed by pull request #1363, but the gazebo5 branch requires additional fixes.

I'll post the build results of this branch when available to confirm the fix.

values.description:
Issue #1387 happens because there is no call to `SetName` of cloned walls when adding new levels.

I generalized `EditorView::Create3DVisual` to be used for all types of items so there are less chances of forgetting a detail like this in the future.
values.title: Building Editor: Use Create3DVisual for all items

summary.raw:
Issue #1387 happens because there is no call to `SetName` of cloned walls when adding new levels.

I generalized `EditorView::Create3DVisual` to be used for all types of items so there are less chances of forgetting a detail like this in the future.
summary.html:
Issue #1387 happens because there is no call to SetName of cloned walls when adding new levels.

I generalized EditorView::Create3DVisual to be used for all types of items so there are less chances of forgetting a detail like this in the future.

values.description: The BulletPlaneShape bounding box always has infinite size (see #1265 and [upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/211)). This causes a problem with drcsim, since AtlasPlugin looks for the bounding box of an object underneath the robot to set the harnessed height. This pull request has a workaround for the issue that allows atlas be re-harnessed over plane shapes with bullet.
values.title: Fix BulletPlaneShape bounding box (#1265)

summary.raw: The BulletPlaneShape bounding box always has infinite size (see #1265 and [upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/211)). This causes a problem with drcsim, since AtlasPlugin looks for the bounding box of an object underneath the robot to set the harnessed height. This pull request has a workaround for the issue that allows atlas be re-harnessed over plane shapes with bullet.
summary.html: The BulletPlaneShape bounding box always has infinite size (see #1265 and upstream issue). This causes a problem with drcsim, since AtlasPlugin looks for the bounding box of an object underneath the robot to set the harnessed height. This pull request has a workaround for the issue that allows atlas be re-harnessed over plane shapes with bullet.

values.description:
The latest version of `protobuf-c` on homebrew generates some warnings when compiling the proto files:
~~~
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on wrench_stamped.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on axis.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on boxgeom.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on camerasensor.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on camera_cmd.proto
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:5411] Warning: Unused import: "camera_cmd.proto" imports "pose.proto" which is not used.
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on collision.proto
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:5411] Warning: Unused import: "collision.proto" imports "header.proto" which is not used.
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on color.proto
...
~~~
This pull request removes the unused import statements.

It is of low importance, but might affect ABI if it's not merged before gazebo 5.0.0

EDIT: these warnings don't appear in our jenkins homebrew jobs since they are using an old patched version of protobuf 2.5.0, but I see the warnings on my laptop, which has the newer protobuf 2.6.0.

UPDATE: I noticed that two of the msgs functions were missing the `GAZEBO_VISIBLE` declaration, so I've added that in msgs.hh
values.title: Remove unused import statements in proto files

summary.html:
The latest version of protobuf-c on homebrew generates some warnings when compiling the proto files:

[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on wrench_stamped.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on axis.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on boxgeom.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on camerasensor.proto
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on camera_cmd.proto
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:5411] Warning: Unused import: "camera_cmd.proto" imports "pose.proto" which is not used.

[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:5411] Warning: Unused import: "collision.proto" imports "header.proto" which is not used.
[ 26%] Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on color.proto
...

This pull request removes the unused import statements.

It is of low importance, but might affect ABI if it's not merged before gazebo 5.0.0

EDIT: these warnings don't appear in our jenkins homebrew jobs since they are using an old patched version of protobuf 2.5.0, but I see the warnings on my laptop, which has the newer protobuf 2.6.0.

UPDATE: I noticed that two of the msgs functions were missing the GAZEBO_VISIBLE declaration, so I've added that in msgs.hh

values.description:
issue #780

This pull request adds `ActuatorPlugin`, a model plugin that enforces a torque limit on a joint based on its current velocity.

Included also is an example in `examples/stand_alone/actuator`. To run:

```
cd <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make install
./actuator
```

This will run an experiment that attempts to command a constant torque on two models that are identical except one uses `ActuatorPlugin` and the other does not.

To plot the data collected from this experiment, use the plotting script provided (matplotlib needed):

```
python <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator/data/plot.py
```

There is one known issue, which is that if a force exceeding the maximum torque for an actuated joint is commanded on the first timestep of simulation, the actuated joint won't enforce the torque-speed curve on that timestep. I think that this problem is hard to fix while this feature remains a plugin but easy to fix if it is incorporated into the main physics library.

![actuator_torque_time_actuated.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2113990264-actuator_torque_time_actuated.png)
![actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4070651820-actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png)
values.title: Actuator plugin (torque-speed curve for joints)

summary.raw:
issue #780

This pull request adds `ActuatorPlugin`, a model plugin that enforces a torque limit on a joint based on its current velocity.

Included also is an example in `examples/stand_alone/actuator`. To run:

```
cd <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make install
./actuator
```

This will run an experiment that attempts to command a constant torque on two models that are identical except one uses `ActuatorPlugin` and the other does not.

To plot the data collected from this experiment, use the plotting script provided (matplotlib needed):

```
python <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator/data/plot.py
```

There is one known issue, which is that if a force exceeding the maximum torque for an actuated joint is commanded on the first timestep of simulation, the actuated joint won't enforce the torque-speed curve on that timestep. I think that this problem is hard to fix while this feature remains a plugin but easy to fix if it is incorporated into the main physics library.

![actuator_torque_time_actuated.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2113990264-actuator_torque_time_actuated.png)
![actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4070651820-actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png)
summary.html:
issue #780

This pull request adds ActuatorPlugin, a model plugin that enforces a torque limit on a joint based on its current velocity.

Included also is an example in examples/stand_alone/actuator. To run:

cd <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make install
./actuator

This will run an experiment that attempts to command a constant torque on two models that are identical except one uses ActuatorPlugin and the other does not.

To plot the data collected from this experiment, use the plotting script provided (matplotlib needed):

python <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator/data/plot.py

There is one known issue, which is that if a force exceeding the maximum torque for an actuated joint is commanded on the first timestep of simulation, the actuated joint won't enforce the torque-speed curve on that timestep. I think that this problem is hard to fix while this feature remains a plugin but easy to fix if it is incorporated into the main physics library.

values.description:
I thought I had fixed all the gazebo OS X issues, but I just found one with DART. It has linking errors for the tools and plugins when dart is installed:
~~~
Linking CXX shared library libContactPlugin.dylib
ld: library not found for -lassimp
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[2]: *** [plugins/libContactPlugin.dylib] Error 1
make[1]: *** [plugins/CMakeFiles/ContactPlugin.dir/all] Error 2
~~~

The fix is easy.
values.title: Fix dart linking errors on osx

summary.raw:
I thought I had fixed all the gazebo OS X issues, but I just found one with DART. It has linking errors for the tools and plugins when dart is installed:
~~~
Linking CXX shared library libContactPlugin.dylib
ld: library not found for -lassimp
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[2]: *** [plugins/libContactPlugin.dylib] Error 1
make[1]: *** [plugins/CMakeFiles/ContactPlugin.dir/all] Error 2
~~~

The fix is easy.
summary.html:
I thought I had fixed all the gazebo OS X issues, but I just found one with DART. It has linking errors for the tools and plugins when dart is installed:

clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[2]: *** [plugins/libContactPlugin.dylib] Error 1
make[1]: *** [plugins/CMakeFiles/ContactPlugin.dir/all] Error 2

The fix is easy.

values.description:
There are several tests in `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the `BulletJoint::GetParam` implementation is moved up to `Joint::GetParam` so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of `BulletHingeJoint::SetParam` and `BulletSliderJoint::SetParam` and added a corresponding test expectation.

This pull request breaks ABI by making `Joint::GetParam` not pure virtual, and deleting `BulletJoint::SetAttribute` and `SimbodyJoint::GetAttribute`. As such it would be nice to include it before gazebo5 code freeze.

I was careful with my commit messages, so I think most of the changes are well explained there.

The content of this is not critical, though the ABI changes are subject to the gazebo5 code freeze date.

Update: I added some ef6b084 private members to `BulletHinge2Joint`. The rest of the code that uses them isn't ready, but I wanted to meet the ABI deadline.
values.title: Enable simbody joint tests, create Joint::GetParam

summary.raw:
There are several tests in `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the `BulletJoint::GetParam` implementation is moved up to `Joint::GetParam` so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of `BulletHingeJoint::SetParam` and `BulletSliderJoint::SetParam` and added a corresponding test expectation.

This pull request breaks ABI by making `Joint::GetParam` not pure virtual, and deleting `BulletJoint::SetAttribute` and `SimbodyJoint::GetAttribute`. As such it would be nice to include it before gazebo5 code freeze.

I was careful with my commit messages, so I think most of the changes are well explained there.

The content of this is not critical, though the ABI changes are subject to the gazebo5 code freeze date.

Update: I added some ef6b084 private members to `BulletHinge2Joint`. The rest of the code that uses them isn't ready, but I wanted to meet the ABI deadline.
summary.html:
There are several tests in INTEGRATION_joint_spawn that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the BulletJoint::GetParam implementation is moved up to Joint::GetParam so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of BulletHingeJoint::SetParam and BulletSliderJoint::SetParam and added a corresponding test expectation.

This pull request breaks ABI by making Joint::GetParam not pure virtual, and deleting BulletJoint::SetAttribute and SimbodyJoint::GetAttribute. As such it would be nice to include it before gazebo5 code freeze.

I was careful with my commit messages, so I think most of the changes are well explained there.

The content of this is not critical, though the ABI changes are subject to the gazebo5 code freeze date.

Update: I added some ef6b084 private members to BulletHinge2Joint. The rest of the code that uses them isn't ready, but I wanted to meet the ABI deadline.

values.description:
Issue #1362

`MeasureItem` properly orients the text in the scene. The problem was that the measures were expressed with respect to the wall, rather than the scene as `MeasureItem` requires.

Make the measures children of the wall segment, as opposed to the door/window (`RectItem`) and express their start and end points in scene coordinates.

![measures4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3076177762-measures4.png)
values.title: Building Editor: Display measure text always upright

summary.raw:
Issue #1362

`MeasureItem` properly orients the text in the scene. The problem was that the measures were expressed with respect to the wall, rather than the scene as `MeasureItem` requires.

Make the measures children of the wall segment, as opposed to the door/window (`RectItem`) and express their start and end points in scene coordinates.

![measures4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3076177762-measures4.png)
summary.html:
Issue #1362

MeasureItem properly orients the text in the scene. The problem was that the measures were expressed with respect to the wall, rather than the scene as MeasureItem requires.

Make the measures children of the wall segment, as opposed to the door/window (RectItem) and express their start and end points in scene coordinates.

values.description:
This is just the ABI changes from pull request #1373.

It removes two unused virtual functions that have already been removed from the parent class:

* BulletJoint::SetAttribute
* SimbodyJoint::SetAttribute

It adds an implementation for `Joint::GetParam`, so it is no longer pure virtual. This allows common code to be shared between physics engines (see pull request #1373).

It adds some private member variables to BulletHinge2Joint that will be needed to fix #494 for revolute2 joints.
values.title: Joint class ABI changes for gazebo5

summary.raw:
This is just the ABI changes from pull request #1373.

It removes two unused virtual functions that have already been removed from the parent class:

* BulletJoint::SetAttribute
* SimbodyJoint::SetAttribute

It adds an implementation for `Joint::GetParam`, so it is no longer pure virtual. This allows common code to be shared between physics engines (see pull request #1373).

It adds some private member variables to BulletHinge2Joint that will be needed to fix #494 for revolute2 joints.
summary.html:
This is just the ABI changes from pull request #1373.

It removes two unused virtual functions that have already been removed from the parent class:

  • BulletJoint::SetAttribute
  • SimbodyJoint::SetAttribute

It adds an implementation for Joint::GetParam, so it is no longer pure virtual. This allows common code to be shared between physics engines (see pull request #1373).

It adds some private member variables to BulletHinge2Joint that will be needed to fix #494 for revolute2 joints.

values.description:
From cppcheck 1.68: "[plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:48] -> [plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:40]: (warning) Array 'joints[4]' accessed at index 4, which is out of bounds. Otherwise condition '_index>=4' is redundant."

We check for out of bounds array access and print a warning message, but then just continue and access memory anyway.
values.title: Prevent out of bounds array access in SkidSteerDrivePlugin (found by cppcheck 1.68)

summary.raw:
From cppcheck 1.68: "[plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:48] -> [plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:40]: (warning) Array 'joints[4]' accessed at index 4, which is out of bounds. Otherwise condition '_index>=4' is redundant."

We check for out of bounds array access and print a warning message, but then just continue and access memory anyway.
summary.html:
From cppcheck 1.68: "[plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:48] -> [plugins/SkidSteerDrivePlugin.cc:40]: (warning) Array 'joints[4]' accessed at index 4, which is out of bounds. Otherwise condition '_index>=4' is redundant."

We check for out of bounds array access and print a warning message, but then just continue and access memory anyway.

values.description:
This uses

```
#!c++

[rendering]
stereo=1/0
```

in `gui.ini` to enable/disable stereo rendering.

This also updates Gazebo to work with Ogre 1.10 (heightmap changes).

values.title: PIMPL'ized Scene class

values.description:
Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made `SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid` to simplify access to the FrictionPyramid data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the `SurfaceParams` object based on the physics engine.

These classes could be PIMPL'ized, but I would save that for a separate pull request.
values.title: Pass Coulomb surface friction parameters to DART

summary.raw:
Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made `SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid` to simplify access to the FrictionPyramid data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the `SurfaceParams` object based on the physics engine.

These classes could be PIMPL'ized, but I would save that for a separate pull request.
summary.html:
Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid to simplify access to the FrictionPyramid data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the SurfaceParams object based on the physics engine.

These classes could be PIMPL'ized, but I would save that for a separate pull request.

values.description:
This patch removes the <gdal/ from all the #includes that are including GDAL headers, as well as adds 'include_directories(${GDAL_INCLUDE_DIR})' to the root CMakeLists.txt

As mentioned in the commit message, I would have put this in a lower level CMakeLists.txt, but the build would not properly parallelize for some reason.

I belive this could also fix issue 1063, related to build problems on Mac OS X where GDAL was detected but headers could not be found.
values.title: Fix for properly including GDAL headers on non-ubuntu systems

summary.raw:
This patch removes the <gdal/ from all the #includes that are including GDAL headers, as well as adds 'include_directories(${GDAL_INCLUDE_DIR})' to the root CMakeLists.txt

As mentioned in the commit message, I would have put this in a lower level CMakeLists.txt, but the build would not properly parallelize for some reason.

I belive this could also fix issue 1063, related to build problems on Mac OS X where GDAL was detected but headers could not be found.
summary.html:
This patch removes the <gdal/ from all the #includes that are including GDAL headers, as well as adds 'include_directories(${GDAL_INCLUDE_DIR})' to the root CMakeLists.txt

As mentioned in the commit message, I would have put this in a lower level CMakeLists.txt, but the build would not properly parallelize for some reason.

I belive this could also fix issue 1063, related to build problems on Mac OS X where GDAL was detected but headers could not be found.

values.description:
Don't include gdal headers in Dem.hh, since this means downstream projects will be exposed to the header, and it's not necessary since we're not using any special data structures in Dem.hh; we just need to include it in HeightmapShape.cc.

We are in code freeze, but this seems critical to me, since it resolves a potential issue with the gazebo5 API. We had several test failures related to downstream projects compiling against gazebo while testing pull request #1388, and this would prevent those types of problems.
values.title: Don't include gdal headers in Dem.hh (gazebo5 API change)

summary.raw:
Don't include gdal headers in Dem.hh, since this means downstream projects will be exposed to the header, and it's not necessary since we're not using any special data structures in Dem.hh; we just need to include it in HeightmapShape.cc.

We are in code freeze, but this seems critical to me, since it resolves a potential issue with the gazebo5 API. We had several test failures related to downstream projects compiling against gazebo while testing pull request #1388, and this would prevent those types of problems.
summary.html:
Don't include gdal headers in Dem.hh, since this means downstream projects will be exposed to the header, and it's not necessary since we're not using any special data structures in Dem.hh; we just need to include it in HeightmapShape.cc.

We are in code freeze, but this seems critical to me, since it resolves a potential issue with the gazebo5 API. We had several test failures related to downstream projects compiling against gazebo while testing pull request #1388, and this would prevent those types of problems.

values.description:
I noticed a [compiler warning with clang on osx](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/379/warnings6Result/package.204417013/):
~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:735:22: warning: variable 'axisMsg' is used
      uninitialized whenever 'if' condition is false [-Wsometimes-uninitialized]
            else if (i == 1)
                     ^~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:738:23: note: uninitialized use occurs here
            msgs::Set(axisMsg->mutable_xyz(), joint->axis[i]);
                      ^~~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:735:18: note: remove the 'if' if its
      condition is always true
            else if (i == 1)
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:732:32: note: initialize the variable
      'axisMsg' to silence this warning
            msgs::Axis *axisMsg;
                               ^
                                = nullptr
~~~
There's a loophole in the logic that could allow an uninitialized pointer to be dereferenced. This small fix prints an error message and skips the pointer dereference.
values.title: Fix warning in JointMaker::Update that axisMsg can be sometimes used uninitialized

/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:735:22: warning: variable 'axisMsg' is used
      uninitialized whenever 'if' condition is false [-Wsometimes-uninitialized]
            else if (i == 1)
                     ^~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:738:23: note: uninitialized use occurs here
            msgs::Set(axisMsg->mutable_xyz(), joint->axis[i]);
                      ^~~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:735:18: note: remove the 'if' if its
      condition is always true
            else if (i == 1)
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/gazebo/gui/model/JointMaker.cc:732:32: note: initialize the variable
      'axisMsg' to silence this warning
            msgs::Axis *axisMsg;

                                = nullptr

There's a loophole in the logic that could allow an uninitialized pointer to be dereferenced. This small fix prints an error message and skips the pointer dereference.

values.description:
* Same saving/exiting flow which was implemented for the Building Editor on pull request #1312, but adapted for the Model Editor:

![popups1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2775725964-popups1.png)

* The Model Editor had been using `gui/SaveDialog` while the Building Editor was using `gui/building/FinishBuildingDialog`. I basically copied `FinishBuildingDialog` into `SaveDialog` and got rid of the original one instead of duplicating code.

* While at it, also PIMPLized `SaveDialog`

* Also moved some functionality from `BuildingMaker` to `SaveDialog`, where it can be used by both editors. Things like `GetFolderNameFromModelName`, `AddDirToModelPaths`, `GenerateConfig`, `SaveToConfig`, and so on.

* Got rid of the save/exit buttons on the palette and added a field for the model name.

* You'll also see a lot of calls to `ModelCreator::ModelChanged`, I hope I was able to track every time the user adds/deletes/modifies something. Currently this is just used to know if there are changes to be saved in the model, but hopefully this will help a future Undo feature.

* Related issues: #1419, #1336, #1326, #1335
values.title: Model Editor: Saving, exiting, generalizing SaveDialog

summary.raw:
* Same saving/exiting flow which was implemented for the Building Editor on pull request #1312, but adapted for the Model Editor:

![popups1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2775725964-popups1.png)

* The Model Editor had been using `gui/SaveDialog` while the Building Editor was using `gui/building/FinishBuildingDialog`. I basically copied `FinishBuildingDialog` into `SaveDialog` and got rid of the original one instead of duplicating code.

* While at it, also PIMPLized `SaveDialog`

* Also moved some functionality from `BuildingMaker` to `SaveDialog`, where it can be used by both editors. Things like `GetFolderNameFromModelName`, `AddDirToModelPaths`, `GenerateConfig`, `SaveToConfig`, and so on.

* Got rid of the save/exit buttons on the palette and added a field for the model name.

* You'll also see a lot of calls to `ModelCreator::ModelChanged`, I hope I was able to track every time the user adds/deletes/modifies something. Currently this is just used to know if there are changes to be saved in the model, but hopefully this will help a future Undo feature.

* Related issues: #1419, #1336, #1326, #1335
summary.html:
• Same saving/exiting flow which was implemented for the Building Editor on pull request #1312, but adapted for the Model Editor:

  • The Model Editor had been using gui/SaveDialog while the Building Editor was using gui/building/FinishBuildingDialog. I basically copied FinishBuildingDialog into SaveDialog and got rid of the original one instead of duplicating code.

  • While at it, also PIMPLized SaveDialog

  • Also moved some functionality from BuildingMaker to SaveDialog, where it can be used by both editors. Things like GetFolderNameFromModelName, AddDirToModelPaths, GenerateConfig, SaveToConfig, and so on.

  • Got rid of the save/exit buttons on the palette and added a field for the model name.

  • You'll also see a lot of calls to ModelCreator::ModelChanged, I hope I was able to track every time the user adds/deletes/modifies something. Currently this is just used to know if there are changes to be saved in the model, but hopefully this will help a future Undo feature.

  • Related issues: #1419, #1336, #1326, #1335
